title: LepEU: European Lepidopteran Population Genomics Consortium

LepEU: European Lepidopteran Population Genomics Consortium
LepEU: European Lepidopteran Population Genomics Consortium
text:
Join Us
If you are interested in butterfly and moth evolutionary dynamics in Europe or elsewhere, you are welcome to join us. To join please complete this questionnaire. This will collect your email, location, question and species interests, how you want to contribute to LepEU, etc. Once completed, a confirmation email will be sent to you. Only then you have been registered properly.

title: LepEU: European Lepidopteran Population Genomics Consortium
text:
Regional collection coordination



North

Finland: Marjo Saastamoinen, University of Helsinki.
Sweden: Niklas Wahlberg, Lund University.
United Kingdom: Joana Meier and Charlotte Wright, Wellcome Sanger Institute.



Central

Poland: Richard Bailey, University of Lodz.
Germany: Matthew Nielsen, University of Bremen.
Switzerland: Kay Lucek, University of Neuchâtel.

France: Mathieu Joron, Centre for Evolutionary and Functional Ecology (CEFE-CNRS).



South

Spain: Constanti Stefanescu, Museum of Natural Sciences of Granollers.
Italy: Emiliano Trucci, Marche Polytechnic University.

title: LepEU: European Lepidopteran Population Genomics Consortium
text:
Web administration and public outreach

Web Administrator: Saad Arif, Oxford Brookes, University, GB.

title: LepEU: European Lepidopteran Population Genomics Consortium
text:
We are a collection of researchers focused upon sampling populations of Lepidoptera species across Europe, to look for patterns of local adaptation across latitudes and through seasons.
Large scale genome sequencing initiatives are now focused upon generating high quality reference genomes for diverse species, including Lepidoptera. By the end of 2024, Project Psyche expects to generate 1000 genomes of European Lepidoptera, with a goal of sequencing nearly all 11,000 within the coming 5 to 10 years.
LepEU is focused upon using these emerging genomes to gain insights into the patterns of local adaption across Europe, exploring how species adapt across latitudes, elevation, and through seasons. We are currently focused upon field collections and will move into data generation in the fall of 2024 for our currently targets species. Our aim is to generate individual level re-sequencing data for diverse populations that are of shared interest to LepEU members.
